questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the ER with rapidly progressing swelling under the jaw and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is bilateral submandibular swelling with elevation of the tongue, but no trismus or fluctuation. He reports recent dental pain in his lower molars. Which anatomical connection is primarily responsible for the rapid bilateral spread of this infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Between the submental and parapharyngeal spaces

options.label: B
options.text: Between the sublingual and retropharyngeal spaces

options.label: C
options.text: Between the submandibular and submental spaces

options.label: D
options.text: Between the submental and buccal spaces

questions.correct_answer: C. Between the submandibular and submental spaces
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’ angina - Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces. (Option C)
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with bilateral submandibular swelling and difficulty swallowing. On examination the swelling is "woody-hard," and the patient exhibits trismus. A CECT scan confirms the presence of diffuse cellulitis without a well-formed abscess. Which of the following is the most critical initial step in managing this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer intravenous corticosteroids to reduce inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an intraoral incision and drainage to relieve pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Conduct a repeat contrast-enhanced CT scan to monitor progression

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate systemic broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’ angina

Clinical Features
  • General Symptoms: Severe difficulty swallowing (odynophagia) and varying degrees of trismus (difficulty opening the mouth).
  • Symptoms depend on infection location and extent:
    • Sublingual Space: Swelling in the floor of the mouth, pushing the tongue upward and backwards.
    • Submandibular Region: Swelling and tenderness in the submandibular area, often described as "woody-hard."
    • Progression: The tongue can displace upward and backward, potentially obstructing the airway, with possible laryngeal edema.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Evaluation: Assess symptoms, including swelling, tenderness, trismus, and airway compromise.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Ultrasound: Identifies abscess presence and location.
    • Contrast-enhanced CT Scan: Differentiates between abscess and cellulitis (Phlegmon), revealing infection extent.

Treatment
  • Systemic Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics to target mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
  • Incision and Drainage: Necessary if an abscess is present. (Option B ruled out)
    • Intraoral Approach: For infections confined to the sublingual space.
    • External Approach: For infections in the submandibular and submental spaces, involving a transverse incision along the mandible.
  • Airway Management: Maintaining a patent airway is crucial; tracheostomy may be needed in severe cases.

Complications
  • Spread of Infection: May extend to the parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces and potentially to the mediastinum, causing mediastinitis.
  • Airway Obstruction
  • Septicaemia
  • Aspiration Pneumonia

questions.text: In the development of a pharyngeal pouch, which anatomical area is primarily affected?
A 65-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, chronic bad breath, and a gurgling sound in his neck during swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Which of the following statements about the parapharyngeal space is/are correct? 1) The parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation. 2) The retropharyngeal space communicates with the parapharyngeal space. 3) The anterior compartment of the parapharyngeal space is related to the medial pterygoid muscle. 4) The posterior compartment of the parapharyngeal space contains the carotid artery, jugular vein, and cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII.
questions.explanation:
Space

Location

Features

Retro- pharyngeal Space
  • Behind the pharynx
  • Extent: from the skull base to tracheal bifurcation. (Statement 1)
  • Infection may spread to the mediastinum.
  • Divided into spaces of Gillette by median raphe.

Pre- vertebral Space
  • Between vertebral bodies (posterior) and prevertebral fascia (anterior)
  • Extent: from the skull base to coccyx
  • Infections often from vertebral caries.
  • Abscess causes a midline bulge.

questions.text: Adult male with complaints of fever, throat pain on left side, painful swallowing with change in voice since 2 days. Oral examination revealed the following. No visible neck swelling is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Collection of pus in the peritonsillar space (between tonsil capsule and superior constrictor muscle).

Aetiology
  • Follows acute tonsillitis or can arise de novo.
  • Infection begins in the tonsillar crypt

Cause
  • Streptococcus pyogenes, S. aureus, anaerobes or mixed infection.

Clinical Features
  • Fever with chills & rigors
  • Severe unilateral throat pain
  • Odynophagia (difficulty swallowing)
  • Muffled "hot potato voice", foul breath
  • Ipsilateral earache (referred via CN IX)

Examination Findings
  • Swollen, congested tonsils, soft palate
  • Uvula pushed to the opposite side with bulging soft palate
  • No visible neck swelling seen

Investigations
  • Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI to show abscess and extent
  • Needle aspiration for bacterial culture and sensitivity testing

Treatment
  • Conservative: IV fluids, Analgesics, IV antibiotics, Oral hygiene (hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwash)
  • Incision and drainage for abscess
  • Surgical: Interval tonsillectomy (after 4–6 weeks)/ Hot tonsillectomy (Tonsillectomy consecutively along with I&D)

Complications
  • Parapharyngeal abscess/ Laryngeal edema
  • Pneumonitis or lung abscess/ Septicaemia
  • Jugular vein thrombosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing, a bulge in the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, and swelling in the parotid region. He also exhibits paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Parapharyngeal abscess in the anterior compartment

options.label: B
options.text: Parapharyngeal abscess in the posterior compartment

options.label: C
options.text: Parapharyngeal abscess in the medial compartment

options.label: D
options.text: Parapharyngeal abscess in the lateral compartment

questions.correct_answer: B. Parapharyngeal abscess in the posterior compartment
questions.explanation:
Parapharyngeal Space
  • Pyramidal in shape
  • Base: skull
  • Apex: hyoid bone
  • Medial: buccopharyngeal fascia
  • Posterior: prevertebral fascia
  • Lateral: medial pterygoid muscle, mandible, deep surface of parotid gland

Aetiology of Infection
  • Pharynx: Acute/chronic infections (tonsil, adenoid), peritonsillar abscess
  • Dental infections: usually lower last molars
  • Ear: Bezold abscess, petrositis
  • Infections of other spaces: Parotid, retropharyngeal, and submaxillary spaces
  • External trauma

Symptoms
  • Fever
  • Odynophagia
  • Sore throat
  • Torticollis
  • Signs of toxaemia

Compartment-wise symptoms
  • Anterior compartment-anterior to styloid process. Abscess here causes:
    • Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa
    • Trismus
    • External swelling behind angle of jaw
  • Posterior compartment-posterior to styloid process. Abscess here causes:
    • Bulge of pharynx behind posterior pillar
    • Paralysis of CN IX, X, XI, XII, and sympathetic chain
    • Parotid region swelling
    • Minimal trismus or tonsillar prolapse

Treatment
  • Systemic antibiotic
  • Drainage of abscess

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and neck pain. On examination, there is a unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall and neck stiffness with limited movement. A lateral neck X-ray reveals a widened prevertebral shadow. What is the etiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: C
options.text: Spread of infection from retropharyngeal lymph node

questions.correct_answer: A. Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall
questions.explanation:
Retropharyngeal space
  • Location: Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia.
  • Extent: From the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • Divisions: Two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) divided by a fibrous raphe.
  • Communication: with parapharyngeal space

Aetiology
  • Children under 3 years (common): suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes from infections in adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.
  • Adults: penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia
  • Breathing difficulty
  • Stridor
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall

Diagnosis
  • X-ray neck lateral view shows widened prevertebral shadow, sometimes even the presence of gas

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals the extent of the abscess

Treatment
  • Incision and drainage
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Tracheostomy if needed

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of untreated tuberculosis presents with mild throat discomfort and difficulty in swallowing. Examination reveals a central fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, and X-rays confirm caries of the cervical spine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Prevertebral space
  • Extent: Base of skull to coccyx
  • Location: Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other

Aetiology
  • Tubercular in nature, caused by:
    • Caries of the cervical spine (central abscess behind prevertebral fascia)
    • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes (unilateral abscess behind buccopharyngeal fascia)

Clinical Features
  • Throat discomfort
  • Mild dysphagia
  • Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline

Treatment
  • Incision and drainage
  • Antitubercular therapy

 

Retropharyngeal

Prevertebral

Location of the space

Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, extending from the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea.

Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other, extenting from the base of skull to coccyx

Etiology

  • Children under 3 years (common)-suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes
  • Adults-penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Tubercular in nature, caused by: Caries of the cervical spine or tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Clinical features

  • Dysphagia
  • Breathing difficulty
  • Stridor
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Throat discomfort
  • Mild dysphagia
  • Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline
